data.title: Well worth it!
data.text: I read about this church here on TripAdvisor. We were very curious about the cemetery below the church. The church offers free tours (please leave a donation) on Saturdays from 11-1:00pm. The tour is short and you are given a rich history of this beautiful church - then they will take you down into the crypt. The church is carefully built right on top of a cemetery. Kinda creepy but very cool.

data.title: A Colonial Church Well Worth The Visit
data.text: Center Church is one of the first meeting houses/ houses of worship on the Green (square). The exterior is slated for restoration work, starting with the steeple, but the interior is a perfect example of sparse eloquence and quiet contemplation. Besides viewing the elegant architecture, there is a fascinating crypt tour you can take below the structure where some of New England's earliest residents reside. This church is definitely worth a visit.

data.title: Happened upon this tour
data.text: We were walking around the green and accidentally found this.  What a treat. The 20 minute free tour gave a brief history of the church and the crypt. The guide was excellent.  Very knowledgeable.  The crypt is fascinating. With head stones from as early as the 1600's.  Discussion included the time period as well as preservation techniques for the headstones.

data.title: Good local history
data.text: Until the end of October, you can get free church and crypt tours on Saturdays. When I went to Yale, I never checked it for some reason, but I did last weekend when I was visting. The church is on the green, which you all know has questionable people all around. Once you get through the riff raff, the church is quiet and plain inside (not bombarded with guadiness). The tour guide was awesome in sharing information about the history of the church. The benches in the churches have some of the names of the early families that rented pews, such as Eli Whitney. The church was built over a cemetery which is, where the crypt came from. The crypt has important residents, such as President Hays' grandmother and Benedict Arnold's first wife. There was some good info about tombstone preservation shared and you got to roam around on your own after the tour. Pictures are allowed everywhere. All-in-all interesting local history for a free 30-minute tour.

data.title: What an impressive place only ruined by all the scumbags!
data.text: Impressive, beautiful, amazing with a few suprisise is my best description of his slice of history! The downside is all of the bums, homeless and thugs in this area ruin the aura around this splendid place!

data.title: DESTRUCTION OF NEW HAVEN GREEN
data.text: It is lovely but it is spoiled by bering on the New Haven Green which has turned into a place where the homeless collect day and night with no police presence. Public urination  problem plus panhandling.. Sad as the whole center of New Haven has been allowed to be ruined as it was once not that long ago  a lovely plACE

data.title: Historical and Sacred!!!
data.text: Center Church is the home of one the oldest continuing congregations in the country, needleless to say there is a lot of history.  The Church itself is from 1812 in the middle of the New Haven Green.  The church is beautiful with its columns and brick façade. The Steeple can be seen from East Rock.  The interior was beautifully designed with a one of a kind chandelier and stained glass depicting the establishment of New Haven. The pews have doors to keep the warm from escaping. The tour guides whom are usually congregants take you to the crypt which is under the church. The church is the resting place of many people. There is an active research and conservation program to preserve the headstones. The last time I went I saw gentleman taking pictures of a headstone belonging to his ancestor. Be careful the ceiling is low watch out for the lights. The tour guides are knowledgeable on the church's past, so ask questions you'll be surprised who has worshiped here in the past. The tours are on certain days so watch for the sign saying "open for tour".  This a place for history buffs, as well as, those looking for a place to worship on Sunday.

data.title: Not open when they say they'll be!
data.text: I stayed an extra day in new haven to see this church and crypt. Their website says they give tours on Thursdays from 10-1. I went there accordingly, and it was all locked up. When I called, the lady on the other end got short with me and treated me like a nuisance.

data.title: Lots of History
data.text: This church has tours of its crypt occasionally (on Saturdays) Well worth it. I lived in New Haven for YEARS before I finally got down there, and was very glad I did. New Haven is teeming with history, and a lot of it is right down there.

data.title: A nice slice of history
data.text: This little-known attraction is rarely open, so check the hours. The crypt contains the old New Haven cemetery with some interesting occupants and lovely gravestones carved with interesting decorations. Some gravestones are from the late 1600's. The stained glass in the church is also lovely and shows the founding of New Haven.

data.title: Awesome
data.text: Be careful, because they only open the crypt on a couple days / week and its for a short time.  A couple church volunteers guide the guests, and the two that greeted us were great people.  Lots of interesting information, very nice.  The crypt was incredible...very interesting, and the volunteer told us all sorts of stuff about it.  There's a donation jar near the front door, but no pressure to put anything in it.

data.title: Very Interesting
data.text: This was a very cool crypt.  Not very large, but has a lot of history.  If in he area make sure you stop by.

data.title: The Historical Center of New Haven
data.text: The Center Church is the oldest religious congregation in New Haven.   At one time, thousands of the early colonists of New Haven were buried on the Green.   The current church was built in 1813, over part of that early cemetery.   The crypt contains tombstones from 1687 to 1812, including that of Benedict Arnold's first wife.  Tours are given on Thursdays and Saturdays from 11-1.   Our tour guide gave a very informative talk about the church, crypt and early settlement of New Haven.

data.title: An underground New Haven gem!
data.text:
Man, I wish I had found out about this years ago! We would've taken all our family members.

I don't want to spoil too much about it, but the haphazard array of 300-year-old tombstones—many of which created by, let's say, people who weren't expert stone carvers—is a sight to behold. The tour is free; our guide kept things speedy while telling us some of the more interesting stories of the church and the people that are buried there. We were even given the chance to explore the crypt on our own (I mean totally on our own; it was spooky) and read the elaborate descriptions on some of the grave markers. Look for the one that goes on for what feels like paragraphs about how smart and wonderful and beloved the interred was; I wanted to laugh out loud...before remembering where I was and what I was reading.

Sadly the "still dead after all these years" t-shirt mentioned in a previous review is no longer available, although they do sell small commemorative plates of the church. Don't forget to leave a donation on the way out; it's worth it.

data.title: Bodies under the Green
data.text: Take a tour of this historic church and see the tombstones of early New Haven residents in the basement that used to be part of the cemetery in the Green.

data.title: Fascinating!
data.text: We really enjoyed the "underground tour" of the cemetery under the church. (for full disclosure our teenage son was not so enamored). If you're interested in colonial history it's certainly worth the time.

data.title: Crypt
data.text: The church itself is beautiful but the crypt tour was so interesting. Creepy to have headstones in the basement but so well preserved. A must see.

data.title: Something different
data.text:
If you get a chance to visit the church and crypt, do it! If you're a planner, like I try to be, do call ahead. We were surprised when we arrived during the crypt tour times posted online (11am-1pm) to find the church completely locked and with no signs indicating why. We walked to the church office a block away and eventually the person there figured out they cancelled tours for the day, but told us to try to visit around 4pm when they were holding a special event. 

Tours are available for the cost of a donation and are very interesting. In the church, you can see Eli Whitney's pew and the crypt tour was very informative (with Benedict Arnold's first wife being one of the burials). Definitely check this one out!

data.title: So cool, creepy, educational, AND fun!
data.text: This tour is the neatest thing.  Church elders guide the tour which includes tons of info on the history of New Haven, the NH Green as well as the Grove Street Cemetery.  Duck your heads and experience a graveyard in the basement of a church.  They used to sell t-shirts ("Still dead after all these years") and I hope they still do!  I visited almost 10 years ago, and that wasn't a timeline choice on Trip Advisor when reviewing, but I encourage you to go if they are still touring.

data.title: Fascinating!
data.text:
Who knew that  Benedict Arnold's first wife  lies  under the church on the Green?  The tour guide was  knowledgeable  and  helpful,  the  headstones  are  so well kept, and  the history  is  so interesting!

I have lived in New Haven for  43 years and just now  discovered this jewel of a piece of American History!
